questions.question: A 65-year-old female presents with acute onset pain, redness, and blurring of vision in the right eye. On examination, her intraocular pressure (IOP) is 48 mmHg, and there is a shallow anterior chamber with a hazy cornea. Slit-lamp examination reveals an intumescent, swollen lens with the iris pushed forward. Gonioscopy shows a closed angle. What is the most likely underlying mechanism for her glaucoma?

options.A: Obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by inflammatory cells
options.B: Forward displacement of the lens due to an abnormal zonular attachment
options.C: Disruption of aqueous humor flow due to posterior synechiae
options.D: Pupillary block caused by the swollen lens

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Pupillary block caused by the swollen lens Explanation: Lens-induced glaucoma is a type of secondary angle-closure glaucoma associated with a disorder of the lens. In this case, the enlarged lens prevents aqueous humor from flowing through the pupil into the anterior chamber, leading to a pupillary block. The iris is pushed forward, resulting in angle closure and increased intraocular pressure. Lens-induced glaucoma can be categorized into the following types: Lens-induced secondary angle-closure glaucoma : Phacomorphic glaucoma: Caused by a swollen or intumescent lens. Phacotopic glaucoma: Due to anterior displacement of the lens. Lens-induced secondary open-angle glaucoma : Phacolytic glaucoma: Results from leakage of lens proteins. Lens particle glaucoma: Triggered by lens fragments in the anterior chamber. Phacoanaphylactic glaucoma: Caused by an immune response to lens proteins. Other options describe mechanisms for other forms of secondary glaucoma, such as uveitic glaucoma (Option A), phacodonesis (Option B), or chronic iritis ( Option C) , but are not characteristic of lens-induced glaucoma. Reference: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 10th edition, Pages 377, 378, 393, 394.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is not typically associated with secondary congenital glaucoma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Angel man syndrome Explanation: Angelman Syndrome (AS) is a rare neurogenetic disorder caused by loss of function of the UBE3A gene on chromosome 15. It primarily affects the nervous system, leading to severe developmental delays, intellectual disability, speech impairment, and movement disorders. Ophthalmic findings that can be seen in Angelman syndrome include Strabismus, Refractive errors, Oculocutaneous albinism, It is not associated with secondary glaucoma. Secondary Developmental/ Congenital Glaucoma Associated Ocular Anomalies Associated Systemic Anomalies Glaucoma Associated with Iridodysgenesis: Aniridia (50% of cases) (Option A ruled out) Familial Iris Hypoplasia Congenital Ectropion Uvea Congenital Microcornea Congenital Nanophthalmos Chromosomal Disorders: Trisomy 13 (Patau Syndrome) Trisomy 18 (Edward’s Syndrome) Trisomy 21 (Down Syndrome) Turner Syndrome (Option C ruled out) Ectopia Lentis Syndromes: Marfan Syndrome (Option B ruled out) Weill-Marchesani Syndrome Homocystinuria Glaucoma Associated with Iridocorneal Dysgenesis: Posterior Embryotoxon: Prominent Schwalbe's ring. Axenfeld-Rieger Syndrome: Axenfeld Anomaly: Posterior embryotoxon with peripheral iris tissue strands. Rieger Anomaly: Posterior embryotoxon, iris hypoplasia, ectropion ,iris defects. Rieger Syndrome: Rieger anomalies with dental, facial, and other systemic anomalies. Peter's Anomaly: Central corneal opacity with or without iris or lens adhesions. Combined Rieger’s Syndrome and Peter’s Anomaly: Features of both conditions. Phakomatosis : Sturge-Weber Syndrome (50% of cases) Von Recklinghausen’s Neurofibromatosis (25% of cases) Metabolic Syndromes: Lowe’s Syndrome: Oculocerebrorenal syndrome. Hurler’s Syndrome: Mucopolysaccharidosis. Zellweger Syndrome: Hepato-cerebral renal syndrome. Reference: https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/1206524-overview?form=fpf https://www.aao.org/education/topic-detail/congenital-glaucoma-europe Parsons Diseases of the Eye, 23rd Edition , Pages 483- 487

questions.question: A 6-month-old infant with congenital glaucoma has corneal enlargement, clouding, and Haab’s striae and the angle is difficult to visualize due to corneal clouding. Which surgical procedure is most appropriate for this infant?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Trabeculotomy with Trabeculectomy Explanation: Congenital glaucoma is diagnosed in this infant based on corneal enlargement , clouding , Haab’s striae , and elevated intraocular pressure. When corneal clouding prevents proper angle visualization, Trabeculotomy with Trabeculectomy becomes the procedure of choice. Trabeculotomy helps expose Schlemm's canal to improve aqueous outflow, and trabeculectomy provides additional filtration, offering better intraocular pressure control. This combined approach is effective when angle visualization is not possible and helps manage congenital glaucoma in infants. Medical Treatment: Purpose : Used to lower intraocular pressure (IOP) until surgery can be performed. Medications : Hyperosmotic agents: Reduce IOP by drawing fluid out of the eye. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: Decrease fluid production. Beta-blockers (e.g., timolol 0.5%): Often the first choice for IOP reduction. Avoid : Miotics: Can paradoxically increase IOP. Alpha-2 agonists (e.g., brimonidine): Contraindicated in children due to CNS depression. Surgical Procedures: Incisional Angle Surgery : Goniotomy : Involves an incision in the angle of the eye using a Barkan’s goniotomy knife, performed under gonioscopic control. Success rate is around 85%. Interestingly, angle surgery is most successful in patients presenting between 2 months and 1 year of age (infantile-onset PCG) with 90% success, and less in newborn or late-recognized PCG with <50% success. In general, IOP control is obtained in greater than 80% of patients. Trabeculotomy : Used when corneal clouding prevents visualization or if goniotomy fails. Involves exposing Schlemm’s canal and breaking the inner wall with a trabeculotome. Filtration Surgery : Trabeculectomy with antimetabolites : Often provides good results. Combined trabeculotomy and trabeculectomy with antimetabolites : Considered a standard procedure for better outcomes. Glaucoma Drainage Devices (GDD) : Used in severe, resistant cases where other methods have failed. Goniotomy (Option A) involves making an incision in the angle of the eye and is best suited when the angle can be visualized clearly. Trabeculectomy with antimetabolites (Option C): While this is a common and effective procedure for many glaucoma cases, it might not be the first choice in this scenario due to the presence of corneal clouding and difficulty in initial angle procedures. Glaucoma Drainage Devices (Option D) are typically reserved for severe, resistant cases when other surgical methods have failed. They are not the first-line approach for the scenario described but might be considered if other surgical options are unsuccessful.

questions.question: A 1-month-old child presents with persistent eye watering and light sensitivity. Examination shows enlarged corneas with Haab’s striae, cloudiness, a deep anterior chamber, and thin, blue sclera. The child has had ocular enlargement since birth. The ophthalmologist suspects congenital glaucoma. Which type of glaucoma best fits this presentation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) True Congenital Glaucoma Explanation: True Congenital Glaucoma is characterized by elevated intraocular pressure present during intrauterine life, resulting in ocular enlargement at birth . The presence of Haab’s striae, early onset, enlarged corneas, and the classic triad of symptoms (watering, photophobia, and blepharospasm) are all consistent with newborn glaucoma. Primary Congenital Glaucoma Types 1. Newborn glaucoma/ True congenital glaucoma : Elevated intraocular pressure is present during intrauterine life, resulting in ocular enlargement at birth . (40% cases) (Option C) Typically presents within the first month of life. Often associated with developmental anomalies of the anterior segment, such as primary congenital glaucoma, which can result from genetic mutations or other congenital conditions. 2. Infantile: ≤ 3 yrs of age - (Option B ruled out) Infantile glaucoma is labelled when the disease manifests prior to the child's third birthday Affects infants older than 1 month and children up to 3 years. Can also result from genetic factors or be secondary to other conditions like Sturge-Weber syndrome or other syndromic associations. 3. Juvenile: > 3 yrs of age (Option A ruled out) who develop pressure rise after 3 years but before adulthood. Also known as Juvenile primary open angle glaucoma(POAG) usually occurs between 10 to 35 years of age. Buphthalmos , meaning "bull-like eyes," is a condition characterized by the enlargement of the eyeball. It typically manifests before the age of 3 years and results from the accumulation and retention of aqueous humor. Pathogenesis Trabeculodysgenesis: Maldevelopment of the trabeculum and iridotrabecular junction from neural crest cells impairs aqueous outflow, causing elevated IOP. Angle Recess Absence: The angle recess is absent, with the iris inserting either flatly or concavely into the trabeculum. Iris Insertion Types: Flat Insertion: Reveals the ciliary body and scleral spur. Concave Insertion: Obscures the scleral spur and ciliary body. Clinical Features Classic Triad: Lacrimation, photophobia, and blepharospasm; often accompanied by eye rubbing. Corneal Signs: Oedema: Early sign, may progress to permanent opacity. Enlargement: Corneal diameter >13 mm confirms enlargement; >16 mm indicates poor prognosis. Haab’s Striae: Tears in Descemet's membrane, visible as opaque lines. Additional Features: Thin Sclera: Appears blue due to underlying uveal tissue. Deep Anterior Chamber: Indicates elevated IOP. Iris Changes: Iridodonesis and atrophic patches in late stages. Lens Changes: Becomes flat and may subluxate. Optic

questions.question: A 50-year-old glaucoma patient is prescribed a prostaglandin analog as first-line therapy. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action and a common side effect of this medication?

options.A: Reduces aqueous humor production; Lid retraction
options.D: Decreases aqueous humor secretion; Allergic blepharoconjunctivitis

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Increases uveoscleral outflow; Iris pigmentation Explanation: Anti-Glaucoma Drugs: 1. Prostaglandin F2 α Agonists (Option C) Examples: Latanoprost, Bimatoprost, Travoprost, Tafluprost Mechanism: Increases uveoscleral outflow Uses: First-line for primary open-angle and angle-closure glaucoma Side Effects: Sandy eyes, orbital fat atrophy, anterior uveitis, cystoid macular edema, heterochromia iridis, hypertrichosis Contraindications: Cystoid macular edema, diabetes mellitus 2. Beta Blockers (Option D) Non-Selective: Timolol, Levobunolol, Carteolol, Metipranolol More effective but contraindicated in asthma Selective: Betaxolol (retinoprotective), Levobetaxolol Safer in asthma Mechanism: Reduces aqueous secretion from ciliary epithelium Side Effects: Allergic blepharoconjunctivitis, dry eyes, corneal hypoesthesia 3. Alpha-2 Agonists (Option A) Examples: Brimonidine (long-term use), Apraclonidine (IOP spikes) Mechanism: Reduces aqueous production, increases uveoscleral outflow Side Effects: Lid retraction, respiratory depression (Brimonidine), allergic blepharoconjunctivitis Contraindications: Children <2 years Brimonidine: Safest during pregnancy (Category B) 4. Miotics (Option B) Examples: Pilocarpine, Physostigmine, Echothiophate Mechanism: Stimulates M3 receptors, increasing trabecular outflow Side Effects: Brow pain, miosis, cataract (Echothiophate), retinal tears 5. Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors Examples: Acetazolamide (systemic), Brinzolamide, Dorzolamide (topical) Mechanism: Inhibits aqueous secretion from ciliary epithelium Uses: Acute congestive glaucoma (with IV mannitol) Side Effects: Ciliary edema, secondary angle-closure glaucoma (Topiramate, Zonisamide) 6. Newer Drugs Netarsudil (Rho kinase inhibitor): Increases trabecular outflow; Side effect - vortex keratopathy Omidenepag (PGE2 agonist): Increases both trabecular and uveoscleral outflow Reference: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 10th edition, Pages 404 - 407

questions.question: All of the following are penetrating glaucoma surgeries except:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Deep Sclerectomy Explanation: In penetrating surgeries an incision is made to create a new drainage pathway, while non-penetrating surgeries aim to enhance the eye’s natural drainage mechanism without incisions. Penetrating surgeries Involves making incisions or creating openings that penetrate the eye's interior to establish a new drainage pathway for aqueous humor. Trabeculectomy is a classic example of a penetrating surgery; Involves resecting the trabecular meshwork and creating a fistula between the anterior chamber and the sub-conjunctival space. A partial-thickness V-shaped scleral incision is made to expose the trabecular meshwork, which is removed using Kelly's punch. An iridectomy is performed to prevent pupillary block. The scleral flap is repositioned and loosely sutured to allow controlled leakage of aqueous humor. A conjunctival flap covers the area, with the presence of a bleb indicating a successful procedure. Non-penetrating surgeries Aim to improve the eye’s natural drainage system without making a fistula. Examples include procedures like deep sclerectomy or viscocanalostomy. They enhance the outflow of aqueous humor by modifying or removing parts of the trabecular meshwork and adjacent structures but do not involve creating a direct drainage pathway through the eye wall. Penetrating surgeries: Trabeculectomy: (Option A) A fistula is created between the anterior chamber and sub tenon's space MCC of failure: fibrosis of fistula To prevent fibrosis , use antimetabolites( mitomycin, 5-FU) The trabecular meshwork is bypassed They have less chance of postoperative complications Glaucoma drainage device / seton surgery: (Option D) It is done in refractory cases , uncontrolled glaucoma and glaucoma with aniridia. Express Implant / Express mini shunt is a modification of trabeculectomy where a needle is used (made up of titanium) instead of a punch. No peripheral iridotomy is done. Ahmed Glaucoma Valve (AGV): Silicon tube and valve with polypropylene body Molteno implant: Silicone tubes with polypropylene plates Baerveldt: Both silicon tube and plate drainage device / seton surgery" data-author="" data-hash="1827" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="March2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/6flNf1LtfBr2EJPi31KA1742979359.png" /> Minimum incision glaucoma surgery: (MIGS): (Option C) In mild to moderate glaucoma with modest target pressure goal. Commonly done with cataract surgery. This is mainly done in combination with phacoemulsification Non penetrating surgeries: Deep sclerectomy Viscocanalostomy Reference: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 10th edition, Pages 416-422 Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd Edition, PDF Pages 725, 726

questions.question: Which of the following laser procedures are used for Open angle glaucoma (OAG) and angle closure glaucoma (ACG) respectively? closure glaucoma glaucoma

options.A: Argon laser iridotomy for open-angle glaucoma and selective laser trabeculoplasty (SLT) for angle
options.B: Selective laser trabeculoplasty for open-angle glaucoma and laser iridotomy for angle closure
options.C: Laser iridoplasty for open-angle glaucoma and argon laser iridotomy for angle closure glaucoma
options.D: Laser iridotomy for open-angle glaucoma and laser iridoplasty for angle closure glaucoma

questions.explanation: angle closure glaucoma Correct Answer: B) Selective laser trabeculoplasty for open-angle glaucoma and laser iridotomy for angle closure glaucoma Explanation: Selective Laser Trabeculoplasty (SLT) It is commonly used for open-angle glaucoma. SLT improves aqueous humor outflow by targeting the trabecular meshwork, which helps lower intraocular pressure over time. Laser trabeculoplasty : There are 2 types: a) Argon Laser trabeculoplasty b) Selective Laser trabeculoplasty- Laser applied selectively to pigmented trabecular meshwork Mechanism of action of argon and Nd: YAG laser is photocoagulation It increases fibrosis in one part, leading to contraction of that area, which then pulls the mesh, leading to the opening of the mesh to the other side. Selective Laser trabeculoplasty is the treatment of choice for prophylaxis in the other eye Laser Iridotomy It is used for angle closure glaucoma. This procedure creates a small hole in the peripheral iris to allow better fluid drainage and relieve the blockage of the anterior chamber angle. This helps lower intraocular pressure and prevent further episodes of angle closure. Argon laser iridotomy (Option A) is used for angle closure glaucoma, not open-angle glaucoma. Also, SLT is not typically used for angle closure glaucoma. Laser iridoplasty (Option C) is used for some cases of angle closure glaucoma, particularly when the angle is very narrow or if iridotomy is not feasible. However, argon laser iridotomy is the more common procedure for angle closure glaucoma. Laser iridoplasty is not used for open-angle glaucoma. Laser iridotomy (Option D) is not used for open-angle glaucoma; it is used for angle-closure glaucoma. Similarly, laser iridoplasty is a treatment for angle closure glaucoma, not open-angle glaucoma. Reference: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 10th edition, Pages 412-416 Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd Edition, PDF Pages 725, 726

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic for a routine eye examination. During the examination, his intraocular pressure (IOP) is measured at 28 mmHg in both eyes. The ophthalmologist diagnoses him with primary open-angle glaucoma. Which of the following medications is primarily designed to lower intraocular pressure by reducing the production of aqueous humor?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Acetazolamide Explanation: Treatment of glaucoma: There are 3 types of treatment modalities: Medical management Laser Surgery 1. Medical: The drugs either decrease the formation of aqueous or increase the drainage to decrease IOP. This is of 2 types: Topical (6 types) Systemic (2 types) Topical: Beta-blockers These decrease the formation of aqueous Eg: Timolol, betaxolol C/I in asthma S/E: corneal anesthesia and blepharoconjunctivitis Alpha agonists: They have dual action i.e. they decrease the formation of aqueous and increase the trabecular outflow. Eg: Adrenaline/epinephrine, dipivefrin, brimonidine, and apraclonidine Brimonidine is safe in pregnancy Adrenaline is C/I in aphakic glaucoma Miotics: These increase the trabecular outflow and open the angle blockage Eg: Pilocarpine (Option B) S/E of Pilocarpine: Pseudo myopia, retinal detachment, shallow anterior chamber, iris cysts Topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: These decrease the formation of aqueous Eg: dorzolamide and brinzolamide These are C/I in sulpha allergies Newer anti-glaucoma drugs: Netarsudil: this increases the contractile property of the trabecular meshwork, thus increasing the trabecular outflow and it also decreases the aqueous production. It is a Rho-kinase inhibitor S/E: vortex keratopathy PGF2 alpha agonist: It increases the uveoscleral outflow These are also contraindicated in uveitis and asthma For eg- Latanoprost, bimatoprost, travoprost (Option A) , tafluprost, and unoprostone isopropyl (Option D) Latanoprost causes heterochromia iridis Bimatoprost increases both uveoscleral and trabecular outflow Side effects: Hypertrichosis Systemic: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor For eg: acetazolamide(Option C) , methazolamide S/E: Tingling and numbness, constipation, renal stones, and a bad metallic taste Hyperosmotic agents: These draw aqueous out of the eye For eg: I/V mannitol (C/I in heart disease), glycerol (C/I in diabetes), isosorbide, and urea 2. Laser : Laser trabeculoplasty can be done using argon laser (ALT), or Micropulse diode (MLT) and selective laser trabeculoplasty (SLT). 3. Surgery : Surgical treatment of POAG primarily consists of a fistulizing (filtration) surgery which provides a new channel for aqueous outflow and successfully controls the IOP . Trabeculectomy is the most frequently performed filtration surgery nowadays. Reference: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 10th edition, Pages 369, 370, 374, 380 Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd Edition, PDF Pages 724, 725

questions.question: Which ICE syndrome is characterized by the presence of pigmented nodular lesions on the iris?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Cogan-Reese syndrome Explanation: Cogan-Reese Syndrome is known for its distinctive iris lesions. It is characterized by the presence of pigmented nodular lesions on the iris, which can be diffuse or localized. These pigmented lesions are a key feature that helps distinguish it from other ICE syndromes. Glaucomas Associated with Iridocorneal Endothelial (ICE) Syndromes: ICE Syndromes Include : Progressive iris atrophy Chandler's syndrome Cogan-Reese syndrome Pathogenesis : Abnormal corneal endothelial cells proliferate to form a membrane at the angle of the anterior chamber. Glaucoma is caused by secondary synechial angle closure due to contraction of this endothelial membrane. Clinical Features : Typically affects middle-aged women . Raised intraocular pressure (IOP) associated with specific features of the causative condition: Progressive iris atrophy : Iris shows corectopia, atrophy, and hole formation. (Options A & D ruled out) Chandler's syndrome : Mild or no iris changes, corneal edema predominates, even at normal IOP. (Option B ruled out) Cogan-Reese syndrome : Iris has pigmented nodular or diffuse lesions (also called iris nevus syndrome), and may have corneal changes. (Option C) Treatment : Glaucoma drainage device (artificial filtration shunt) may help control IOP. Medical treatment is often ineffective . Trabeculectomy surgery usually fails. Reference: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 10th edition, Pages 397, 398

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about traumatic glaucoma?

options.A: Traumatic glaucoma can develop from both perforating and blunt injuries.
options.B: Angle recession glaucoma typically presents with elevated IOP shortly after the trauma.
options.C: Lens-induced glaucoma can occur due to a ruptured, swollen, or dislocated lens following trauma.
options.D: Peripheral anterior synechiae from corneal injury can lead to angle-closure glaucoma.

questions.explanation: trauma. Correct Answer: B) Angle recession glaucoma typically presents with elevated IOP shortly after the trauma. Explanation: Angle recession glaucoma often develops months to years after the initial blunt trauma due to long-term fibrosis of the trabecular meshwork. It is not typically associated with immediate elevated IOP. Traumatic Glaucoma A secondary glaucoma may complicate perforating as well as blunt injuries. (Option A ruled out) Causes: Inflammatory Glaucoma: Results from iridocyclitis. Intraocular Hemorrhage: Hyphaema inside the eye leading to glaucoma. Lens-Induced Glaucoma: Due to a ruptured, swollen, or dislocated lens. (Option C ruled out) Angle-Closure: Caused by peripheral anterior synechiae formation after corneal injury. (Option D ruled out) Epithelial or Fibrous Infiltration: May involve the trabecular meshwork. Angle Recession Glaucoma : Due to angle recession (The recession is due to a tear in the ciliary body) from blunt trauma after years (10yrs), leading to fibrosis of the trabecular meshwork over time. (Option B) Management : Medical Therapy : Includes topical 0.5% timolol and oral acetazolamide. Treatment of Underlying Causes : For instance, using atropine and steroids to control inflammation. Surgical Intervention : Based on the specific cause and situation.

questions.question: A 30-year-old male presents with unilateral eye discomfort, blurred vision, and seeing halos around lights. On examination, his intraocular pressure (IOP) is measured at 48 mm Hg. The anterior segment shows a few small, flat, nonpigmented keratic precipitates located inferiorly, mild redness, and an aqueous flare. The pupil is dilated, but there are no signs of a posterior synechiae. The patient reports recurrent episodes that resolve within days to weeks. Given these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: Secondary Angle-Closure Glaucoma with Pupillary Block
options.B: Secondary Angle-Closure Glaucoma without Pupillary Block

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Glaucomatocyclitic Crisis Explanation: Glaucomatocyclitic Crisis (Posner-Schlossman Syndrome) is characterized by very high IOP (often between 40 and 50 mm Hg), minimal inflammation, a few small keratic precipitates, no posterior synechiae, and recurrent episodes that resolve within days to weeks. The treatment involves controlling IOP with anti-glaucoma medications, followed by steroid therapy to manage the uveitis. Glaucoma Associated with Uveitis Types: 1. Secondary Angle-closure glaucoma with a pupillary block (Option A): Caused by pupillary block due to annular synechiae, leading to iris bombe and subsequent angle closure. 2. Secondary Angle-closure glaucoma without a pupillary block (Option B) : Results from inflammatory debris organizing in the angle, which pulls the iris over the trabecular meshwork, causing progressive angle closure and elevated IOP. 3. Open-angle glaucoma (Option C) : This is caused by the blocking/inflammation of the trabecular meshwork by aqueous cells. 4. Specific Hypertensive Uveitis Syndromes: Glaucomatocyclitic crisis Uveitis with Open-Angle Glaucoma (Glaucomatocyclitic Crisis) It is called glaucomatocyclitic crisis or PSS (Posner-Schlossman Syndrome) or hypertensive uveitis (There is high intraocular pressure). The glaucoma is out of proportion to the minimal inflammation present. The condition is characterized by acute, recurrent episodes that resolve within days to weeks. Recurrence is common. Etiology: It is commonly seen in young males. This can be due to HLA-BW54 association has been documented. CMV or H. Pylori infection. Pathogenesis: It is caused due to trabeculitis and blocking of trabecular meshwork happening due to uveitis. On examination Keratic Precipitates: Few small, flat, nonpigmented keratic precipitates, typically located inferiorly. Dilated pupil. Aqueous Flare is present. No posterior synechiae Intraocular pressure: Very high, often between 40 and 50 mm Hg. White eye (no congestion) Treatment The treatment of choice is anti-glaucoma drugs and once IOP is under control, steroids are given. Thus, steroids are given under anti-glaucoma cover.

questions.question: A 70-year-old patient with a history of glaucoma undergoes a trabeculectomy to control intraocular pressure. Postoperatively, the patient presents with severe eye pain, blurred vision, a significantly elevated intraocular pressure (IOP), and a shallow anterior chamber. Seidel's test is negative. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Atropine drops and oral acetazolamide Explanation: The clinical scenario describes a 70-year-old patient who, following trabeculectomy , experiences severe eye pain and blurred vision, elevated intraocular pressure (IOP), a shallow anterior chamber, a negative Seidel's test, which are characteristic of ciliary block glaucoma (malignant glaucoma). This condition occurs due to a mechanical blockage of aqueous humor flow, often after intraocular surgery. Initial Treatment for Malignant Glaucoma: Atropine Drops: These are used to dilate the ciliary ring and alleviate the ciliary block causing the increased IOP and shallow anterior chamber. Oral Acetazolamide: This carbonic anhydrase inhibitor helps reduce aqueous humor production, which is crucial for managing the elevated IOP in ciliary block glaucoma. Ciliary Block Glaucoma (Malignant Glaucoma/ Aqueous misdirection syndrome) A rare form of glaucoma that may occur as a complication of intraocular surgery. Characterized by markedly raised intraocular pressure (IOP) and a shallow or absent anterior chamber. Causes Post-surgical Complication: Common after peripheral iridectomy (Option D ruled out) , trabeculectomy, cataract surgery, capsulotomy, and laser iridotomy. Mechanism Cilio-Lenticular Block: In phakic eyes, the ciliary processes rotate forward and press against the lens. Cilio-IOL Block: In pseudophakic eyes, the ciliary processes press against the intraocular lens. Cilio-Vitreal Block: In aphakic eyes, the ciliary processes press against the anterior hyaloid face of the vitreous. Outcome: Blocks forward flow of aqueous humor, causing aqueous pockets to form in the vitreous, pushing the iris-lens diaphragm forward, increasing IOP, and flattening the anterior chamber. Clinical Features Symptoms: Severe pain and blurred vision post-intraocular surgery. Signs: Persistent shallow anterior chamber following surgery. Markedly raised IOP in the early postoperative period. Negative Seidel's test ( Seidel’s test : Tear film is stained to detect leakage of aqueous from the anterior chamber) Poor response or aggravation by miotics. anterior chamber " data-author="Wang, Jie & Du, Ergang & Tang, Jinfei." data-hash="1796" data-license="CC BY 4.0" data-source="https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Shallow-a nterior-chamber-observed-by-slitlamp-biomicroscopy-in-the-right-eye-a-and-in_fig1_323364968" data-tags="March2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/sGNrtEFbWPEZThQkOo1U1742976012.png" /> Types: Can be phakic, aphakic, or pseudophakic. Management Medical Therapy (Initial): Atropine

questions.question: A 58-y/o diabetic patient presents with decreased vision, eye pain, and redness in the right eye. Examination reveals iris neovascularization, elevated intraocular pressure, and proliferative diabetic retinopathy. What is the most appropriate management strategy?

options.A: Topical beta-blockers and oral carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Panretinal photocoagulation Explanation: Based on these findings, the diagnosis of neovascular glaucoma is supported by the presence of iris neovascularization and elevated IOP in the context of proliferative diabetic retinopathy. Panretinal photocoagulation is the most appropriate treatment as it targets the underlying cause of neovascular glaucoma. This treats the retinal ischemia, reducing the stimulus for abnormal blood vessel growth and neovascularization. Neovascular Glaucoma (NVG) NVG is a severe type of glaucoma caused by neovascularization (abnormal blood vessel growth) in the iris and anterior chamber angle of the eye. Causes : Common : Proliferative diabetic retinopathy Central retinal vein occlusion Sickle-cell retinopathy Eales' disease Rare : Chronic intraocular inflammation Intraocular tumors Long-standing retinal detachment Central retinal artery occlusion Mechanism : Neovascularization (rubeosis iridis) on the iris leads to fibrosis. Results in zip-like adhesions of the iris to the cornea at the angle. Stages : Pre-glaucomatous Stage : Presence of rubeosis iridis (neovascularization of the iris). Open-Angle Glaucoma Stage : Formation of a pretrabecular neovascular membrane, leading to increased intraocular pressure (IOP). Secondary Angle Closure Glaucoma Stage : Neovascular membrane causes goniosynechiae (adhesions) leading to angle closure. Treatment : Panretinal Photocoagulation or Cryotherapy : Aimed at preventing further neovascularization. Anti-VEGF Agents : Used as an adjunctive treatment . Help reduce neovascularization. (Option D) Medical Therapy : Often ineffective for controlling IOP. Trabeculectomy : A surgical procedure to lower intraocular pressure, often combined with antifibroblastic agents. Glaucoma Drainage Device : Artificial filtration shunt (Seton operation) can help manage IOP. Topical beta-blockers and oral carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (Option A): These medications can help manage intraocular pressure (IOP) but do not address the underlying cause of neovascular glaucoma, which is the retinal ischemia and resulting neovascularization. Systemic corticosteroids (Option C): While corticosteroids can reduce inflammation, they do not address neovascularization or the elevated IOP associated with neovascular glaucoma. They are not the primary treatment for this condition.

questions.question: A 55-year-old Asian woman presents with acute eye pain and blurred vision. Her ophthalmologist suspects primary angle closure glaucoma (PACG). Which of the following statements about the etiopathogenesis of PACG is incorrect?

options.A: Pupillary block is the most common mechanism in PACG
options.B: Phacomorphic mechanism involves an abnormally large lens pushing the iris forward
options.C: Plateau iris configuration is more common in younger patients with PACG
options.D: Caucasians have a higher prevalence of PACG compared to other ethnicities

questions.explanation: etiopathogenesis mechanisms for primary angle closure glaucoma (PACG) are given in the table below: Risk Factors Mechanisms Demographic factors: Age: 6th and 7th decades of life Gender: Female to male ratio 1:3 Ethnicity: More common in Asians 1. Pupillary block (70% of cases): (Option A ruled out) Most common mechanism (70% of cases) Increased contact between iris and lens Precipitating factors: Physiological mydriasis (e.g., dim illumination, emotional stress) Pharmacological mydriasis (e.g., tropicamide, cyclopentolate) Results in relative pupil block Anatomical factors: Hypermetropic eyes Shallow anterior chamber Short axial length Thick, anteriorly positioned lens Small corneal diameter Plateau iris configuration 2. Plateau iris configuration: Anteriorly positioned ciliary processes More common in younger patients (Option C ruled out) Can persist after iridotomy Associated with angle closure glaucoma without pupillary block Other factors: Family history Diabetes mellitus Certain medications (e.g., topiramate) 3. Phacomorphic mechanism: (Option B ruled out) Swollen lens contributes to angle closure Can cause pupillary block or push peripheral iris forward Can occur in acute or chronic forms Associated with intumescent or other lens morphological abnormalities Reference: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 10th edition, Pages 372 - 374

questions.question: A 72-year-old male presents with diminution of vision in the right eye. On slit-lamp examination, dandruff-like material is noted on the anterior lens capsule and iris. Intraocular pressure is elevated, and the patient is diagnosed with pseudoexfoliative glaucoma. Which of the following is most likely to be observed in this patient’s eye?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Zonular instability and phacodonesis. Explanation: Zonular instability is a hallmark of pseudoexfoliation syndrome , where the accumulation of pseudoexfoliative material weakens the zonular fibers. This can lead to phacodonesis (lens wobbling). Ocular manifestation of Pseudoexfoliation Syndrome (XFS) is characterized by the accumulation of fibrillar, proteinaceous material on various ocular structures, including the lens, iris, and trabecular meshwork. This material can be seen as flaky white deposits on the anterior lens capsule and pupillary margin, often with a distinct clear zone at the center of the lens. It causes secondary open-angle glaucoma, known as pseudoexfoliative glaucoma. The excessive material and pigment clog the trabecular meshwork, increasing intraocular pressure (IOP) and causing damage to the optic nerve, which leads to glaucoma. It also predisposes patients to complications during cataract surgery due to weakened zonules, resulting in lens instability or phacodonesis. Features of Pseudoexfoliation Syndrome: White flaky deposits on the anterior lens capsule and iris Increased trabecular meshwork pigmentation Elevated IOP, leading to secondary glaucoma Zonular instability and risk of lens dislocation during cataract surgery Mutations in the LOXL1 gene have been strongly associated with PXF, although not all individuals with these mutations develop the disease. More prevalent in elderly patients. Posterior synechiae (Option A) is incorrect because while inflammation can lead to synechiae, it is not a primary feature of pseudoexfoliation syndrome. Corneal guttata (Option C) is associated with Fuchs' endothelial dystrophy, not pseudoexfoliation syndrome. Iris heterochromia (Option D) is typically seen in Fuchs' heterochromic iridocyclitis, not pseudoexfoliation syndrome. Reference: Yanoff and Duker's Ophthalmology, 5th Edition, Page 1074-1077 Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 10th Edition, Page 382, 383, 384

questions.question: A 25-year-old myopic male presents with intermittent blurring of vision and mild ocular pain after exercise. On examination, IOP is 28 mmHg, Slit lamp examination reveals Krukenberg spindle on corneal endothelium, trabecular pigmentation on gonioscopy. Which of the following is the first-line treatment?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Topical prostaglandin analogue Explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with pigmentary glaucoma. The key features are: 1. Young, myopic male 2. Elevated IOP 3. Krukenberg spindle (vertical line of pigment on corneal endothelium) 4. Heavily pigmented trabecular meshwork 5. Iris transillumination defects 6. Symptoms exacerbated by exercise (due to pupillary movement causing increased pigment release) Pigmentary glaucoma: Pigmentary glaucoma is a form of secondary open-angle glaucoma characterized by clogging up of the trabecular meshwork caused by the pigment particles. Pigment release may be caused by mechanical rubbing of the posterior pigment layer of the iris with the zonular fibrils. It is more common in young, myopic males. Pigment granules are deposited in anterior segment structures, including the iris, the posterior surface of the cornea ( Krukenberg’s spindle ), the trabecular meshwork, ciliary zonules, and the crystalline lens. On gonioscopy, pigment is seen accumulating along Schwalbe’s line , particularly in the inferior region ( Sampaolesi's line ). Iris transillumination reveals radial, slit-like defects in the mid-periphery, which is a characteristic feature. Treatment is along the lines of POAG management, which initially includes medical treatment, with prostaglandin analogues often being the first choice due to their IOP-lowering efficacy and convenient dosing schedule. (Option C) Nd:YAG laser peripheral iridotomy (Option A) is not the first-line treatment. It is generally reserved for cases with pronounced iris concavity or those not responding to medical therapy. Selective laser trabeculoplasty (SLT) (Option B) is typically considered after initial medical therapy or in combination with it. Argon laser peripheral iridoplasty (Option D) is primarily used in angle-closure glaucoma to open the angle. It is not typically used in pigmentary glaucoma, where the angle is already open. Reference: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 10th edition, Pages 385, 386, 387 Effects of jogging exercise on patients with the pigmentary dispersion syndrome and pigmentary glaucoma

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with unilateral eye pain, redness, and moderately elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) of 28 mmHg. On slit-lamp examination, you observe fine, pigmented deposits on the corneal endothelium in a vertical spindle pattern. The patient O/E has symmetric transillumination defects in the mid-peripheral iris. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's secondary glaucoma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Pigment dispersion syndrome Explanation: Pigment dispersion syndrome occurs when pigment granules from the iris epithelium are released into the anterior chamber and deposit on various structures, including the corneal endothelium and trabecular meshwork. This can lead to trabecular outflow obstruction and subsequent glaucoma. Symmetric Iris transillumination defects in the mid-peripheral iris, is characteristic of Pigment Dispersion Syndrome (PDS) . Secondary Glaucoma: Secondary glaucoma refers to elevated intraocular pressure resulting from an identifiable ocular or systemic disorder. Unlike primary glaucomas, secondary glaucomas have a clear underlying cause that alters the aqueous humor dynamics, leading to increased IOP and subsequent optic nerve damage. Causes of Secondary Glaucoma: Lens-induced glaucomas (phacomorphic, phacolytic, lens-particle) Pigmentary glaucoma Pseudoexfoliative glaucoma Neovascular glaucoma Inflammatory glaucoma (uveitic) Traumatic glaucoma Steroid-induced glaucoma Glaucoma-in-aphakia Iridocorneal endothelial syndrome (ICE syndrome) Aqueous misdirection syndrome (malignant glaucoma) Glaucomas associated with intraocular hemorrhage. Glaucoma associated with intraocular tumors. Pseudoexfoliation syndrome (Option A) presents with whitish, dandruff-like material on the lens capsule and pupillary margin. Transillumination defects can also be seen in Pseudoexfoliation syndrome but they are usually patchy and irregular. Gonioscopy may show increased pigment deposition on the trabecular meshwork. Neovascular glaucoma (Option C) is characterized by new blood vessel growth over the iris and anterior chamber angle, often secondary to ischemic retinal diseases. It typically presents with a red eye, severe pain, and very high IOP. Lens-particle glaucoma (Option D) occurs when lens material enters the anterior chamber, usually after cataract surgery or lens injury. Reference: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 10th Edition, Page 382, 385, 387

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents with a painful, blind right eye. On examination, the eye is stony hard with no light perception, 100% cupping of the optic disc, and a fixed, mid-dilated pupil. Which of the following is the correct initial management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Cyclodestructive procedure Explanation: Absolute glaucoma is the final phase of Primary Angle Closure Glaucoma. Clinical features of Absolute Glaucoma are: Painful blind eye. A ciliary flush around the cornea due to dilated ciliary veins, and in long-standing cases, caput medusae with prominent vessels. Cornea - initially clear but insensitive, later becoming hazy, with epithelial bullae (bullous keratopathy) or filaments (filamentary keratitis). Anterior chamber - very shallow. Iris - atrophic. Pupil - fixed and dilated. Optic disc - glaucomatous optic atrophy. IOP is high and the eyeball becomes stony hard. Management of absolute glaucoma In absolute glaucoma, the goal of treatment is to relieve pain and reduce IOP, as vision cannot be restored. Retrobulbar alcohol injection - given to relieve pain. First, 1 mL of 2% xylocaine is injected followed after about 5-10 minutes by 1 mL of 80% alcohol. It suppresses the ciliary ganglion. A cyclodestructive procedure, such as cyclocryotherapy or cyclophotocoagulation, is the most appropriate management option in this scenario as it reduces aqueous production by damaging the secretory ciliary processes aiming to reduce IOP. (Option C) If pain persists despite cyclodestruction, enucleation/ evisceration may be considered. (Option D) Topical timolol and brimonidine (Option A) are incorrect because medical management with topical medications is insufficient for absolute glaucoma. Trabeculectomy (Option B) is incorrect because filtration surgery is not indicated in absolute glaucoma. The eye is already blind, and there is a high risk of complications such as hypotony, choroidal effusion, or suprachoroidal hemorrhage in eyes with such advanced disease. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3669490/#:~:text=An%20eye%20that%20has%20lost,other% 20cases%2C%20it%20may%20not . Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 10th edition, Pages 379, 380, 381.

questions.question: All of the following components of Vogt's triad are typically observed in a patient who has experienced and resolved an acute primary angle-closure glaucoma (APAC) attack except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Progressive retinal damage Explanation: Vogt's triad is a clinical set of findings typically associated with acute primary angle-closure glaucoma (APAC) after an attack has been resolved. The triad helps in identifying damage caused during the acute episode. Features of APAC: Descemet membrane folds Iris atrophy Irregular pupil Glaucoma flecken Cataract Cupping +/- Vogt’s triad: (Option A, B, C) It may be seen in both treated and non-treated cases after an attack of acute PAC. It is characterized by: Dispersion of pigment on cornea Glaucoma flecken (Opacities develops d/t necrosis of anterior epithelial cells of the lens) Patches of iris atrophy Reference: Parson’s Textbook of Ophthalmology, 23rd Edition, Page 704 https://journals.lww.com/ijog/fulltext/2023/03020/vogt_s_triad___do_we_find_the_triad_all_the_time_.118.aspx

questions.question: A 55-year-old female presents for a routine eye examination. During gonioscopy, the examination reveals an occludable anterior chamber angle bilaterally. The patient reports no visual symptoms, and intraocular pressure (IOP) measurements are within normal limits. There is no evidence of glaucomatous damage on optic nerve examination. What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Prophylactic peripheral iridotomy Explanation: PACS is characterized by an occludable anterior chamber angle as seen during gonioscopy but without evidence of increased IOP or glaucomatous damage. This indicates a risk for potential future angle closure but does not yet present as acute angle-closure glaucoma. PACS: Primary Angle Closure Suspect Iridotrabecular contact or occludable angle of more than 3 quadrants on gonioscopy No peripheral anterior synechiae Intraocular pressure is normal Eclipse sign of PACS - convex iris lens diaphragm Treatment : Prophylactic Peripheral iridotomy (Option B) is done in both eyes with lens extraction using NdYAG laser PAC: Primary Angle Closure Iridotrabecular contact or occludable angle of more than 3 quadrants PAS+/- ( by indentation gonioscopy) Raised IOP Treatment: Prophylactic Peripheral iridotomy and control of IOP I.V Mannitol/Acetazolamide (Option A) is treatment of choice to decrease the pressure in cases of acute primary angle closure (APAC) / Acute congestive glaucoma Filtration surgery (Option C) i.e. trabeculectomy should be performed in cases where IOP is not controlled with the maximum medical therapy following an attack of acute PAC or when gonioscopy reveals PAS >270° angle and also when peripheral iridotomy is not effective. Topical beta-blocker therapy (Option D) is used to lower IOP in patients with glaucoma but is not appropriate for a patient with narrow angles without elevated IOP. Reference: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 10th Edition, Page 375, 376, 381, 382 Parson’s Textbook of Ophthalmology, 23rd Edition, Page 702, 706

questions.question: What aspect of the anterior chamber does the Van Herick grading system evaluate during slit lamp examination?

options.B: The width of the anterior chamber angle

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) The width of the anterior chamber angle Explanation: The VAN Herick technique is an eye examination method used to determine the width of the anterior chamber angle of the eye using the ratio of the anterior chamber depth and corneal section which gives the status of the angle as per the chart given below. Width of the empty space (LACD) as compared to the corneal thickness VAN Herick Grade Angle status No black space observed 0 Closed <¼ corneal thickness 1 Extremely narrow ¼ of corneal thickness 2 Narrow >¼ to ½ of corneal thickness 3 Open ≥ 1/2 of corneal thickness 4 Wide open LACD = Limbal anterior Chamber depth The curvature of the cornea (Option A): The curvature of the cornea is assessed using a keratometer or topographer. The condition of the retina (Option C): VAN Herick technique is used to estimate the anterior chamber angle (ACA) and not th condition of the retina. The intraocular pressure (Option D): Measuring intraocular pressure is done with a tonometer. Reference: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 10th edition, Pages 375, 376 Interobserver reliability when using the Van Herick method to measure anterior chamber depth - PMC (nih.gov)

questions.question: In the Shaffer classification system for grading the anterior chamber angle, which grade indicates that the angle is fully open with visible structures such as the scleral spur and trabecular meshwork?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Grade 3 Explanation: The Shaffer system is one of the various methods used to grade the angle during the gonioscopy. The angle in degree between two imaginary lines is tangential to the inner surface of trabecular meshwork and the interior surface of the iris (1/3rd distance from the periphery) When the iris is in a normal position it will open up to 45 degrees, and it decreases with various problems. When it keeps on decreasing the angle structures will be different on gonioscopy. They are graded according to the following chart. Grade 0 (Option A): The angle is closed with no visible structures; only the iris and cornea are seen. Grade 1 (Option B): The angle is very narrow, and only a small portion of the angle structure, such as the iris insertion, is visible. Grade 2 (Option C): The angle is moderately open; structures like the trabecular meshwork are partially visible. ACA in degrees ACA grade Angle status Visible structures 0 0 Closed No structures visible </= 10 1 Extremely narrow Schwalbe’s line 11-19 2 Narrow Trabecular meshwork 20-34 3 Open Scleral spur 35-45 4 Wide open Ciliary body ACA= Anterior Chamber Angle Reference: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 10th edition, Page 388 https://www.researchgate.net/figure/ACA-grading-system-as-described-by-Shaffer_tbl2_276494875 https://www.researchgate.net/publication/360211495_Comparison_of_Iridocorneal_Angle_Assessments_in_Open A ngle_Glaucoma_and_Ocular_Hypertension_Patients_Anterior_Segment_Optical_Coherence_Tomography_and_G onioscopy

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the principle of gonioscopy?

options.B: It is a technique for visualizing the anterior chamber angle of the eye using a special lens
options.C: It is a technique for visualizing the posterior chamber angle of the eye using a special lens

questions.explanation: special lens Correct Answer: B) It is a technique for visualizing the anterior chamber angle of the eye using a special lens. Explanation: Gonioscopy is the main method used to measure the angle of the anterior chamber The angled structure is not visible to the examiner because of the total internal reflection inside the anterior chamber. Principle: It overcomes total internal reflection Critical angle = 46 degree A Gonioscope with the same refractive index as the cornea and mirror is placed over the cornea. Light from the anterior chamber strikes the cornea and travels through and gets reflected by the mirror in the gonioscope, thus reaching our eye. Structures in the angle of the anterior chamber that can be visualized by gonioscope Ciliary body band Scleral spur Trabecular meshwork Schwalbe’s line (peripheral termination of descemet's membrane) Measuring intraocular pressure is done with a tonometer, not a gonioscopy. (Option A) It is a technique for visualizing the anterior chamber angle of the eye using a special lens and not the posterior chamber. (Option C) The retina is evaluated with a fundus camera or other retinal imaging techniques, not gonioscopy. (Option D)

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents with intermittent eye pain and blurred vision. Gonioscopy reveals narrow angles, and the angle remains narrow after laser peripheral iridotomy. Which of the following statements about plateau iris configuration is incorrect ?

options.A: It is characterized by an anteriorly positioned ciliary body
options.B: It is more commonly seen in older patients with primary angle closure glaucoma
options.C: Plateau iris configuration can persist after iridotomy
options.D: Ultrasound biomicroscopy (UBM) can be useful in diagnosing this condition

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) It is more commonly seen in older patients with primary angle closure glaucoma glaucoma, not older patients. Plateau Iris Configuration Anatomy Plateau iris is characterized by an anteriorly positioned ciliary body, which pushes the peripheral iris forward. This creates a "table-top" or plateau-like appearance of the iris. Age of presentation It is more commonly seen in younger patients with primary angle closure glaucoma. This is in contrast to the pupillary block, which is more common in older individuals. Diagnostic tools Ultrasound biomicroscopy (UBM) is particularly useful in diagnosing plateau iris configuration. (Option D) Management Due to its persistence after iridotomy, patients with plateau iris may require additional treatments such as: (Option C) Argon laser peripheral iridoplasty Long-term use of miotic drops iris configuration" data-author="Imrankabirhossain " data-hash="1779" data-license="CC BY-SA 4.0 " data-source="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plateau_iris#/media/File:Plateau_iris.jpg" data-tags="March2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/kNo6RgS1IhBIs2w2tJFH1742972082.png" /> Reference: Pubmed Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 10th edition, Pages 375, 376, 377

questions.question: A 50-year-old patient presents with symptoms suggesting possible angle-closure glaucoma. You want to perform a comprehensive assessment of the anterior chamber angle. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding anterior chamber angle assessment and anatomy? trabecular meshwork, pigmented trabecular meshwork, scleral spur, and ciliary body band. 180 degrees without indentation.

options.A: Gonioscopy is the definitive diagnostic tool for primary angle closure.
options.B: Normal angle structures from anterior to posterior include: Schwalbe's line, non-pigmented
options.C: An angle is considered occludable if the pigmented trabecular meshwork is not visible in less than
options.D: Indirect gonioscopes used to measure angle of AC are goldmann, posner-ritch, zeiss

questions.explanation: visible in less than 180 degrees without indentation. 180 degrees , not less than 180 degrees. Occludable angle: Defined as when the posterior trabecular meshwork is not visible in more than 180 degrees without indentation or manipulation Associated with a shallow anterior chamber The angle recess in such eyes is generally less than 20° Can be further evaluated with a dark room prone provocative test Tools for anterior chamber angle assessment include: Gonioscopy- Definitive Diagnosis (Option A ruled out) Van-Herick Method Grading the angle - Shaffer system Ultrasound biomicroscopy (UBM)-50 MHz AS-OCT: Non-Contact Method There are 2 types of gonioscopy lenses: Indirect (Option D ruled out) Direct Provides a mirror image of the opposite angle Provides a direct view of the angle Example : 1. Goldmann lenses Single mirror Surger Two mirror Three mirror 2. Zeiss 3. Susman 4. Posner – Ritch Example: 1. Koeppe 2. Swan – Jacob Normal angle structures from anterior to posterior: (Option B ruled out) Schwalbe's line Non-Pigmented trabecular meshwork Pigmented Trabecular meshwork Scleral spur Ciliary body band Iris Reference: Pubmed Parson’s Textbook of Ophthalmology, 23rd Edition, Page 702 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7759936/
